src:
Dozens rescued after Philippine ferry capsizes

07 Nov 2019, 16:32

MANILA: Philippine authorities rescued dozens of people on Thursday (Nov 7) after a ferry sank in rough seas, but search teams were still working to confirm all aboard were accounted for, the coast guard said.
Rescuers plucked 59 people from waters off the central island of Cebu, while another three swam to shore after the vessel took on water and capsized.
Advertisement
Advertisement
The manifest showed 60 crew and passengers aboard, the coast guard said, however it is not clear if the list was complete.


Passengers of the ill-fated MV Siargao Princess ferry being rescued from the waters off Sibunga Cebu in the central Philippines. (Photo: AFP/Philippine coast Guard/ Handout)

Manifests in the Philippines are often not a full accounting because passengers may stow away or captains can exceed the official capacity of their vessel.
"Rescue operations are ongoing. We cannot stop until we are satisfied that everyone is safe and has been accounted for," coast guard spokesman Lieutenant Michael Encina told AFP.
"The boat has sunk. We haven't been able to find it," he added.
The vessel, Siargao Princess, was plying a route near Cebu when its crew radioed for help, saying the boat was in trouble.

READ: Three dead, more than 240 rescued after Philippine ferry blaze



Philippine authorities launched a rescue operation on Nov 7 after a ferry with at least 60 people onboard capsized in rough seas, the coast guard said. (Photo: AFP/Philippine coast Guard/Handout)

The Philippines, an archipelago where millions rely on rickety ferries for cheap transport between islands, has regular boat accidents.
Source: AFP/nr
